ALLEGATION #1:
On 6/13/22, two youth allegedly engaged in sexual activity in the bathroom at the
facility. Afterward, one youth experienced vaginal burning and was diagnosed with
bacterial vaginitis.
INVESTIGATION:
Safehaus Too is a 6-bed therapeutic group home contracted by community mental
health and located in a residential neighborhood in Warren Michigan. The agency works
directly with each youth’s parent/guardian and does not contract with MDHHS.
This intake was initially transferred to DCWL from another government agency on
6/15/22. By the end of the business day, the decision was reconsidered, and it was
assigned to Government Worker 1. I contacted the complainant. He had no additional
concerns.
I arrived at the facility unannounced on 6/15/22 and met with the Chief Administrator
(CA). When the incident occurred, CA said there were three youths in the facility and
one staff (Former Staff 1) was providing direct care. CA estimated the inappropriate
contact between youths happened between 9 – 11pm after the youths went into their
rooms for the night but were not asleep. Afterward, Youth D complained of vaginal
burning and was taken to urgent care on 6/14/22.
I reviewed the following documents on-site:
 Incident report by Staff 2 dated 6/13/22
 Written statements from Youth’s D, A and S dated 6/14/22
 Room monitoring logs for Youths D and A dated 6/13/22
 Case Management notes for Youths D and A dated 6/14/22.
 Nursing note for Youth D dated 6/14/22
 Former Staff 1’s employee file
 I requested discharge instructions for Youth D’s urgent care visit on 6/14/22, but
they were not available. CA said the nurses who transported her did not receive
any written instructions.
An incident report by Staff 2 dated 6/13/22 at 11:47pm indicated:
“When I arrived at 10:49pm to work (Safehaus Too) I was asking Former Staff 1 about
how many residents in the house and their names when I noticed Youth S was
complaining of a stomachache. Youth D was in the bathroom already. Former Staff 1
was finishing up her job duties and getting ready to go home. Former Staff 1 informed
3

me that Youths S and D was both having stomach problems and keep using the
bathroom. Once Former Staff 1 left I was starting on my paperwork when Youth D
asked me can she come talk to me about something. I said yes and that’s when Youth
D started shaking and about to cry, telling me that her stomach wasn’t hurting, but her
private part was burning really bad, and that it was because her and Youth A had snuck
in the bathroom while Former Staff 1 was busy and had sex. Youth D said it had just
happened right before I got there and that’s why she needed medical attention. When
Youth D told me it was me and her, then when Staff 3 came in, she stated that it
happened when staff was busy again. Youth D was moved to Main at 12am and the
proper calls were made to her mother and Supervisor 1.”
Room monitoring logs for Youths D and A showed Former Staff 1 checked the youths
every 15 minutes on the quarter hour between 9pm and 11pm and that both youths
were awake. Documentation showed the youths were not however checked at variable
intervals per licensing rule requirements. Additionally, the room monitoring log for Youth
A showed Staff 2 missed two checks between 11p – 12am.
Case management notes for Youths D and A verified that both youths’ parents were
notified of the incident on 6/13/22.
The nursing note by LPN 1 dated 6/14/22 indicated:
“Patient (Youth D) was taken to urgent care for vaginal irritation. Pt. was diagnosed with
Bacterial Vaginosis and Yeast Infection. She was given a dose of Rocephin ABT
prophylactic. Urgent care called in a prescription for Doxycycline, Diflucan and Flagyl. Pt
was instructed by Urgent care to not take the Doxycycline until STD test results come
in.” As indicated above, discharge instructions from the urgent care facility were not
available.
A written statement by Youth D, age 15, dated 6/14/22 read “Last night the staff was
sleep and I ask him to come to the bathroom with me and we had the lights off and
pants down and we did it and I was burning after that.”
A written statement by Youth A, age 14, dated 6/18/22 (he meant 6/14) read “She asked
me to do something sexual and I was feel peer pressured so I fingered her.”
A written statement by Youth S, age 12, dated 6/14/22 read “She told me. I didn’t see it.
She said that she made him do it finger her.” A second statement by Youth S dated
6/15/22 read “She made him go in the bathroom and I walk in on the them and I went
back in my room, and she told me she was going to tell them and he never touched
me.”
I was unable to interview Youths D, A and S as they had all been discharged to their
parents on 6/14/22. CA said Youth D was discharged because her parents were “very
upset” when they were notified about what happened and that Youth A wanted to be
discharged because of what happened.
4

I was unable to interview Former Staff 1 because she was terminated for failing to
provide continuous adequate supervision to the residents on 6/13/22.
I interviewed the Human Resources Manager (HRM). HRM said she interviewed Former
Staff 1 before terminating her. Former Staff 1 reportedly told HRM that when the youths
were awake in their rooms, she was sitting in the hall between their rooms with her head
down working on electronic files. HRM said based on Youth D and A’s statements that
they entered the bathroom together, she determined Former Staff 1 failed to provide
continuous supervision to the residents. I inquired about Former Staff 1’s history of
written discipline. HRM viewed her employee file and indicated that Former Staff 1 had
eight disciplinary write-ups for sleeping on duty during the past six years.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: The written youth statements and findings from HRM are
evidence that Former Staff 1 was not providing continuous and
adequate supervision to the youths allowing them to enter the
bathroom together. Former Staff 1’s employment was
terminated on 6/14/22.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
5

ANALYSIS: On the night of 6/13/22, Former Staff 1 documented 15-minute
checks of the youth. However, the checks were performed on
the quarter hour and not at variable intervals. Also, Staff 2 failed
to complete two checks on Youth A between 11pm – 12am.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION #2
The same youth was also given a double dose of medication twice during her brief stay
at the facility.
INVESTIGATION:
Youth D was at Safehaus Too for less than 48 hours. She was admitted the night of
6/12/22 and discharged on 6/14/22 at 2:10pm.
I interviewed LPN 1 by phone. She said that Youth D was admitted to the facility with
her own prescribed medication. Youth D’s medication count sheet was initialed by LPNs
1 and 2 and listed Escitalopram 5mg and Aripiprazole 5 mg one tablet daily, and
Escitalopram 10mg one tablet at bedtime. A review of the medication log indicates
Youth D received one tablet of Escitalopram 5mg on 6/13, one tablet of Escitalopram
10mg at bedtime on 6/13, and one tablet of Aripiprazole 5mg on 6/13 & 6/14. The
medication count sheet was consistent with the medication log. All documents indicated
Youth D’s medication was properly dispensed and she was not given “double doses.”
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written
health service policies and procedures addressing all
of the following:
(e) dispensing medication
6

ANALYSIS: The medication log indicates Youth D received the appropriate
doses of her prescribed medication at the appropriate times.
There is no evidence she received double doses or that her
medication was improperly dispensed.
CONSULTATION
I recommended that staff accompanying a youth to an
emergency medical visit be required by the agency to obtain the
written discharge instructions to ensure that appropriate medical
follow up occurs.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Once an acceptable corrective action plan is received, I recommend this facility
continue its current licensing status.

sir_summary.summary: A 2022 investigation at Safehaus Too, a child therapeutic group home, substantiated that on June 13th, two youth engaged in sexual activity in a bathroom while under staff supervision. The facility failed to provide continuous, adequate supervision, with staff performing room checks at fixed intervals instead of variable ones as required. The facility is culpable for inadequate supervision protocols and staff performance, leading to the incident and subsequent youth discharges, while a secondary allegation of improper medication dispensing was not substantiated.
